rsbNotes.title: Ps 79
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 79 The destruction of the temple (v. 1) dates this psalm to the period after the Babylonian defeat of Jerusalem in 586 b.c.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 79:1
rsbNotes.text: 79:1 the nations have come into your inheritance. Because the people disobeyed God’s covenant, He did what He had warned them He would do (Deut. 28:15–68), sending a foreign nation against them. Both city and temple were destroyed at this time (2 Kin. 25; 2 Chr. 36:15–23; Lamentations).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 79:2
rsbNotes.text: 79:2 your servants . . . your faithful. The faithful also suffered at the hands of the Babylonians. The psalmist singles out the death of the faithful as he appeals to God for restoration.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 79:5
rsbNotes.text:
79:5 How long, O Lord. This is a prayer to God to change a hard situation.

jealousy. A synonym for anger.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 79:6
rsbNotes.text: 79:6 Pour out your anger on the nations. The poet calls for a reversal, asking God to turn His wrath from Israel to the nations God was using to punish them. In the end the Lord answered the psalmist’s prayer, restoring Israel and destroying Babylon.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 79:8
rsbNotes.text: 79:8 former iniquities. This psalm may have been written some time after the destruction of Jerusalem. The chief sin was idolatry, turning to false gods.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 79:11
rsbNotes.text: 79:11 the prisoners. The writer knows that God has a special place in His heart for the oppressed and vulnerable, so he reminds Him of those who need Him (9:18 note).
